title: Will the unemployment rate for the United Arab Emirates (UAE) exceed 5.00% in 2020?
preds: The primary job sectors, Construction, Manufacturing, Oil should all get hit by the covid impact to the global economy. Seems more likely that this could result in a doubling of employment then previous worst
Many people losing jobs have no residency rights and are therefore forced to leave being omitted from statistics and ensuring the underlying rate remains low.

Revised down to 0% in line with the latest figures.
A boost has also been given to business in the UAE by the Kingdom by allowing 100% foreign ownership for certain sectors. https://tradingeconomics.com/united-arab-emirates/unemployment-rate  https://www.globenewswire.com/news-release/2020/03/26/2006808/0/en/Middle-East-Macroeconomic-Insights-2015-2025-Presents-Economic-Demographic-Employment-Infrastructure-Competitiveness-Data-for-14-Countries.html  https://www.khaleejtimes.com/business/local/uae-clears-100-ownership-rules
Okuns Law would suggest a real possibility to reach 5% but past experience does not warrant this claim.
Dropping this to zero. Per my earlier forecasts, this will be highly unlikely.
I believe the way UAE unemployment is counted is fairly gamed, with only certain classes of citizens counted as 'employed.'

UAE is still far from 5% and coronavirus inside the country is quite under control. tourism's share of GDP is around 12% which is also relatively small. additionally, UAE labour laws are quite modern and there are expats leaving the country leaving more jobs for locals

Previous economic crisis around the globe has not affected the rate in the UAE to a large degree and 5% is significantly higher than any previous impact, in addition the current rate is low compared to 5%

Over the last two decades, the peak unemployment rate in the UAE was only 3.12%, with an average closer to 2.25%. Daily coronavirus cases and deaths have been decreasing and the curve appears to have been flattened across the nation, suggesting that unemployment will not rise any more than it already has due to the pandemic. Last year closed at 2.35%, and while an increase this year is entirely possible, it is unlikely to exceed more than 4.00% total unemployment.

@keith-huggins makes good points. Historically, the biggest in unemployment has been 0.82%, and unemployment has never surpassed 3.12%. @mattlerner pointed out the COVID-19 may not be hitting the UAE (or at least the Emiratis) as badly as one might think.

In the United Arab Emirates, the unemployment rate measures the number of people actively looking for a job as a percentage of the labour force. The assumption here is that only Emirati citizens are to be accounted for, as expatriates require sponsorship by employers.
UAE population is made up of 88.52% expatriates and 11.48% Emiratis. 
The unemployment rate in the UAE is measured by those actively requiring a job as a percentage  of the pool of labour.
Population of the UAE is 9.63 million
Population of Emiratis is 1.1 Million.
48%  or 529,000 of Emiratis are  in the employment pool.
91% of employed Emiratis work for the Government, local Government or quasi-government organisations.
Private companies have to employ Emiratis depending on size on a quotia system.
Government has programs in place to employ all Emiratis throughout the states of the emirates. 
Current unemployment rate is 2.35 % which is 12431 people looking for work.
5% is 26450 and require a doubling of the unemployment numbers.
https://www.google.com/search?client=safari&rls=en&q=emirati+population+of+uae&ie=UTF-8&oe=UTF-8  https://tradingeconomics.com/united-arab-emirates/unemployment-rate  https://www.globalmediainsight.com/blog/uae-population-statistics/  http://pubdocs.worldbank.org/en/879771554825521024/mpo-are.pdf
https://www.bakermckenzie.com/en/insight/publications/2020/03/support-for-employers-in-the-uae-covid19  https://u.ae/en/information-and-services/jobs/uae-workforce  https://www.thenational.ae/uae/10-charts-that-paint-a-picture-of-emiratisation-1.917664  https://www.edarabia.com/population-uae/ https://www.macrotrends.net/countries/ARE/uae/unemployment-rate

Possibly. Lot's of good points flying around.
A month ago there was a hiring rebound, and again, if 3.12 was the worst in 2005 (no mention of 2008) then 5% feels like a monumental hurdle. Also, worth noting is that news is noticeably quiet on the subject.
Oil prices are low.  Travel is low.  Tourism is low.  While immigrants are more likely to be affected (are they accounted in the numbers) there will be know on impact by the end of the year.

Thanks to @mattlerner for the provided source [1,2]. [1] https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1071392
[2] https://www.thenational.ae/business/job-applications-in-uae-soar-during-coronavirus-pandemic-1.1031025

Incrementing very slightly down here on the basis of this article (https://www.thenational.ae/business/job-applications-in-uae-soar-during-coronavirus-pandemic-1.1031025) - if it's true that demand for white collar work is up, that's good news for Emirati citizens (not migrant workers), who are highly educated.

Found an article regarding unemployment numbers for UAE citizens (population of citizens: 1.4 million) [1]: as of a month ago, there are about 12k unemployed, which the article seems to imply is high. This gives some insight to the jobless number that is reported: it is some sort of a representation of the ex-pat unemployment rate and probably has little to do with reality (the highest reported is 3.1% [2]). I am bringing my estimate way down. [1] https://gulfnews.com/uae/government/push-for-jobless-emiratis-to-be-paid-unemployment-benefits-1.71830082
[2] https://www.indexmundi.com/facts/united-arab-emirates/indicator/SL.UEM.TOTL.ZS

No, The UAE job maket depends on a large EXPAT population, to obtain and high unemployment level and sustain that for a period there would need to bee a large number of out of work people looking for a job, but If you are out of work in the UAE you only have a very limited time to look for a job before you have to leave the country and return home.  So this is not to say that high levels of people currently employed in the UAE won't loose their jobs, just that they wont appear in the country specific metric.
No indication that this is coming

The UAE has a higher percentage of type O blood persons, who are more resistant to the virus. The more information we get, the less dangerous the virus turns out to be. I do expect the global recession to get worse, but not because of the virus.
While the rate might reach 4% I don't foresee 5% reached, especially as the highest value over the last 29 years was 3.12.
Very unlikely. There is still significant work to support the World Cup 2022 and as long as there is a vaccine on the horizon, UAE will still press.
One is the way the unemployment is record it, two the UAE ships out folks very rapidly if their contracts are terminated!

No numbers are available for UAE unemployment. Every hit seems to reference US numbers. Hints I can get: many people are looking for work based on applications submitted through job sites (though many jobs seem to be available), and there has been a substantial stimulus package (approx 76 billion USD) given to small and medium-sized businesses [1]. I am going to stick with my current for now, as no information revises my previous analysis of how they can cook their books [2]. [1] https://www.thenational.ae/business/job-applications-in-uae-soar-during-coronavirus-pandemic-1.1031025
[2] https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1038077
The global economy is in a free fall. It seems very unlikely UAE will reverse this trend. Unemployment will go above 8% in 2020.
Historical trend. Has not already hit.

Oil prices have fallen recently  but global demand for vehicle fuel will gradually rise now implementation of post Corona virus guidelines take effect. Demand for EV and other green fuel types will taper.
A threshold of 5% in the current climate is a low threshold to pass.  The virus is only just starting to hit the gulf states in all seriousness.  And consequences take some time to arrive.
past trends predict increase but not above 5%
Trends show an increase in unemployment of 1.2% and that will be below the 5%

When people lose their job in UAE they leave the country. This creates an artificially low representation of unemployment. I know a great deal of people who have left already, are about to leave, or are considering leaving. Often this is not related to job losses, but as a result of re-evaluating life due to recent events. Another factor driving people to leave is the high cost of living. With an exodus of talent from the UAE, there will be job opportunities created. Combined with the fact that people leave if they have no job, it reasons to believe that unemployment will remain artificially low and not an accurate measure of the economy. I've put 25% chance only because of the short term nature of the question, with the anticipation that some people will remain in the UAE and try to find a job for a few months. This will increase the unemployment percentage temporarily.
Between the current glut, and the slowing down of production it should drive up their unemployment rate for a short while.

In reality there is 0% chance that it won’t be >5%. I’m just doubting because they can play with nr’s to let it seem that they are doing good. But it’s almost impossible to keep it that low.
A lot of expats are leaving(also friend of mine), they will create disruptions to the economy there... also Emirates in a lot of trouble,... https://www.bloomberg.com/amp/news/articles/2020-06-10/expats-are-leaving-dubai-and-that-s-bad-news-for-the-economy?__twitter_impression=true
Tight control of cvd19would mean a low impact on local economy

Last 15 year average has never touched 5% and this includes the financial crisis and SARS. The only factor that impacts now is the pandemic and it is estimated to cause another 1.2% from the projected 2.8% for 2020. That means, the higher limit is 4.0%. However, with the cancellation of expo, oil crisis and other service sectors badly exposed to the pandemic, there are chances to push the limit slightly higher and again this could be offset by monetary stimulus. To offset this, the government could make more efforts to promote more women participation in the private sector and also encourage local entrepreneurship.

At the height of the global financial crisis in 2009, UAE unemployment did not rise above 2.5%, despite having jumped above 3% in the years prior to the crisis. This is some (small) indication that the indicator may not be so responsive to global trends. This (https://www.thenational.ae/business/uae-labour-force-by-sector-graphic-1.53217) is a few years old, but it seems to indicate that only around 15% of the labor force is engaged in extractive industries, hotels and restaurants (presumably the hardest-hit by the crisis). The U.S. economy may hit 20% unemployment--let's say 18%--this year, for a roughly fivefold multiple over 2019. If we see that in the UAE, that would make for 11.5% unemployment. But the lack of responsiveness of the UAE unemployment numbers to the previous global financial crisis suggests that the state takes some measures to "adjust" these numbers. Here are three measures for which I've found some evidence. (1) employment of Emirati nationals by the public sector (apparently ~80%). (2) "flexibility" in the way labor force data is collected. (3) shipping migrant workers out of the country. I'm going to start off at 20%.
Economical crisis will lead to a lot of unemployment, but by the way through low employment rights they will send the unemployed working people to their home countries and out of the statistics.
Call it confirmation bias but @chiefthe and @RRG summed up my initial hunch.

The question is not whether things are bad in the UAE (it is) and whether it could get worse in 2020 (it might). The UAE is dependent to a degree on tourism/services and its airline(s) industry, these being the glue that binds everything together. And these have been the worst hit in the pandemic.  The question is how well IndexMundi will reflect the state on the ground. And IndexMundi might well be correct from their perspective. The UAE is a country with an 80% migrant population and a 90% migrant workforce. This could lead to low reported unemployment even when the country as a whole sheds 30% of its jobs. This could explain how IndexMundi reports a small jump from 2.33 to 2.70 in 2008 to 2009 - while these years were BAD for the UAE. I believe there would be an uptick in the unemployment rate reported by IndexMundi for the UAE, it could go to 3.50 maybe even 4.25/4.50. But exceeding 5.00 seems slim as of now. Would like to start with a baseline estimate of 15% for Yes.

This is really tricky. Since many of the non-working in the UAE are not UAE citizens [1] it is not clear to me if they would count in the UAE unemployment numbers, as they have to be tied to an employer, even if they are not being paid. UAE citizens are getting 60% of their paychecks during the lockdown [1]. With that in mind, Emirates has cut 30k jobs [2], and a survey notes that 70% of Dubai's businesses could go bust due to the COVID crisis [3]. All this and low oil prices, make things not look good for getting loans paid back and could cause a general collapse [4]. But, it should be noted that although the UAE was hard hit in 2009 [4], there was barely a blip in their unemployment rate around that time [5].  So, the question seems to me if the government has enough money to keep its own citizens in jobs through 2020. That seems possible, since they have a pretty good amount of cash reserves currently [6]. With that, it seems like this will be a low probability for now. [1] https://asiatimes.com/2020/05/who-is-to-blame-for-gulfs-deserted-labor-force/
[2] https://www.aerospace-technology.com/news/emirates-coronavirus-uae-jobs/
[3] https://english.alaraby.co.uk/english/news/2020/5/21/dubai-warns-that-70-percent-businesses-could-go-bust
[4] https://www.reuters.com/article/emirates-banks-sp/uae-banks-risk-rise-in-bad-loans-after-virus-triple-whammy-sp-idUSL8N2D32W0
[5] https://www.indexmundi.com/facts/united-arab-emirates/indicator/SL.UEM.TOTL.ZS
[6] https://gulfnews.com/uae/uae-has-third-largest-cash-reserves-in-arab-states-1.355740

Knee-jerk prediction, will investigate further:
Rationale being... I just don't know enough about this to comment. If 3.12% is the current ceiling, the road to 5% is long. Maybe 4.5% is the new ceiling... maybe 4%.
